articles.headline: Teetering on Failure, but Meeting Standards
articles.snippet: A rapidly growing bank that paid consistent dividends may soon become the largest bank to fail in 2009.
articles.abstract: A rapidly growing bank that paid consistent dividends may soon become the largest bank to fail in 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert E. Lowder believed in growth. He steered his bank into areas where the population was rising rapidly, acquiring dozens of small banks in states like Florida and Nevada. He then accelerated that growth with generous lending to builders. His bank made it a point to raise its dividend to shareholders every year.

articles.headline: Netscape Founder Backs New Browser
articles.snippet: Now a prominent financier, Marc Andreessen is backing a start-up called RockMelt that is building a new Internet browser.
articles.abstract: Now a prominent financier, Marc Andreessen is backing a start-up called RockMelt that is building a new Internet browser.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  It has been 15 years since Marc Andreessen developed the Netscape Internet browser that introduced millions of people to the Internet.

articles.headline: Senators Investigate Hospital Purchasing
articles.snippet: Private companies negotiate prices of medical goods, and Medicare reimburses hospitals. But lawmakers fear that the process may inflate health costs.
articles.abstract: Private companies negotiate prices of medical goods, and Medicare reimburses hospitals. But lawmakers fear that the process may inflate health costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers eager to broaden health care coverage while holding down costs are examining the institutional market for medical supplies, a largely unseen $60 billion-a-year realm where things like bedpans and heart implants change hands.

articles.headline: Europe’s Surge Signals Hope for Economic Recovery
articles.snippet: The unexpected surge showed just how far Europe and the global economy had come since a harrowing free fall in late 2008.
articles.abstract: The unexpected surge showed just how far Europe and the global economy had come since a harrowing free fall in late 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  The European economy bounced back with unexpected strength in the second quarter, buoying hopes that a worldwide recession was drawing to a close.

articles.headline: Woman Tells of Affair With Madoff in New Book
articles.snippet: Sheryl Weinstein, the chief financial officer of an organization that invested with Bernard L. Madoff, will soon release a memoir disclosing the relationship.
articles.abstract: Sheryl Weinstein, the chief financial officer of an organization that invested with Bernard L. Madoff, will soon release a memoir disclosing the relationship.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hadassah, the Jewish volunteer organization, knew it had invested $40 million with Bernard L. Madoff by the late 1990s. It also knew it had taken more than $130 million from its Madoff accounts and still had millions on the books when the vast Ponzi scheme was revealed in December.
articles.byline: By Diana B. Henriques and Stephanie Strom

articles.headline: China Warms to New Credo: Business First
articles.snippet: China is finding it harder to separate domestic politics from its aggressive push into the global business arena.
articles.abstract: China is finding it harder to separate domestic politics from its aggressive push into the global business arena.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  So far this week, the World Trade Organization has rebuffed China in an important case involving Chinese restrictions on imported books and movies. The Chinese government dropped explosive espionage charges against executives of a foreign mining giant, the Anglo-Australian Rio Tinto, after a global corporate outcry. And on Thursday, the government said it had backed off another contentious plan to install censorship software on all new computers sold here.

articles.headline: Care to Write Army Doctrine? With ID, Log On
articles.snippet: The Army has begun encouraging its personnel to go online and collaboratively rewrite some of the manuals that guide Army life.
articles.abstract: The Army has begun encouraging its personnel to go online and collaboratively rewrite some of the manuals that guide Army life.
articles.lead_paragraph: Join the Army, where you can edit all that you can edit.

articles.headline: G.M.’s Unit for Investing to Attract Pay Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Traders at Promark Global Advisors accounted for many of the top 25 earners at General Motors.
articles.abstract: Traders at Promark Global Advisors accounted for many of the top 25 earners at General Motors.
articles.lead_paragraph: They work for General Motors but pull down Wall Street-style bonuses  and that is raising some eyebrows in Washington.

articles.headline: Judges’ Dissents for Death Row Inmates Are Rising
articles.snippet: Some judges have complained that death row prisoners face daunting barriers to appeal their convictions.
articles.abstract: Some judges have complained that death row prisoners face daunting barriers to appeal their convictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: It took just 80 words for a federal appeals court to deny Kevin Cooper’s most recent plea to avoid execution. But attached to that order was a forceful 101-page dissent by a judge, all but pleading to spare Mr. Cooper’s life.
